title: DeFACT in ManuVerse for Parallel Manufacturing: Foundation Models and Parallel Workers in Smart Factories
abstract: In cyber–physical–social systems, smart manufacturing has to overcome challenges, such as uncertainty, diversity, complexity in modeling, long-delayed responses to market changes, and human engineer dependency. DeFACT is a framework of parallel manufacturing in ManuVerse where the Decentralized Autonomous Organization-based interactions between parallel workers consisting of robotic, digital, and human workers are elaborated to transform from professional division to real-virtual division. In DeFACT, human workers are only responsible for 5% physical and mental work that is complex and creative, and the robotic and digital workers can take care of the rest. The perceptual and cognitive intelligence of digital workers are intensified by a manufacturing foundation model (MF-PC), where calibration and certification (C&C), and verification and validation (V&V) guarantee not only the accuracy of task models, but also the interpretability and controllability of feature learning. As a case study, the workflow of customized shoes of SANBODY Technology Company is illustrated to show how DeFACT breaks the time and space constraints, avoids production waste caused by aesthetic discrepancies with consumers, and truly realizes flexible manufacturing.

Abstract—In cyber–physical–social systems, smart manu-
facturing has to overcome challenges, such as uncertainty,
diversity, complexity in modeling, long-delayed responses to
market changes, and human engineer dependency. DeFACT is
a framework of parallel manufacturing in ManuVerse where
the Decentralized Autonomous Organization-based interactions
between parallel workers consisting of robotic, digital, and
human workers are elaborated to transform from professional
division to real-virtual division. In DeFACT, human workers are
only responsible for 5% physical and mental work that is com-
plex and creative, and the robotic and digital workers can take
care of the rest. The perceptual and cognitive intelligence of digi-
tal workers are intensiﬁed by a manufacturing foundation model
(MF-PC), where calibration and certiﬁcation (C&C), and veri-
ﬁcation and validation (V&V) guarantee not only the accuracy
of task models, but also the interpretability and controllability
of feature learning. As a case study, the workﬂow of customized
shoes of SANBODY Technology Company is illustrated to show
how DeFACT breaks the time and space constraints, avoids pro-
duction waste caused by aesthetic discrepancies with consumers,
and truly realizes ﬂexible manufacturing.
Index Terms —Artiﬁcial systems, computational experi-
ments, and parallel execution (ACP), cyber–physical–social
systems (CPSSs), decentralized autonomous organization (DAO),

I. I NTRODUCTION
A
S AN advanced manufacturing pattern, smart manufac-
turing has received high regard in many countries, which
have proposed corresponding development strategies accord-
ing to their national conditions, such as Industry 4.0 [ 1], Made
in China 2025 [2], and Industrial Internet [3]. With the contin-
uous development of social networks and informationization,
the engineering systems are also evolving with the integration
of human society and physical industry, which is far beyond
the ability of cyber–physical systems (CPSs) and the Internet
of Things (IoT) to deal with [4], [5], and [6]. Therefore, cyber–
physical–social systems (CPSSs) and the Internet of Minds
(IoM) have become new infrastructures of smart manufac-
turing [ 7], [ 8], where knowledge automation (KA) exerts a
vital role in the exploration of their applications, whereby
Industry 5.0 will become a reality [ 9], [10].
To achieve smart manufacturing, there are several challenges
to overcome for the current manufacturing pattern. First, in
CPSS, human, and social behaviors with the characteristics of
uncertainty, diversity, and complexity exacerbate cognitive or
modeling gaps between actual systems and their models [ 11];
second, long-delayed responses to market changes and fail-
ure to properly comprehend customer requirements result in
less competitive products and inventory accumulation; ﬁnally,
the operations of some equipment rely on human engineers’
demonstrations and even quite a few manual interventions
are required in automated production processes, which is nei-
ther ﬂexible nor efﬁcient [ 12]. Most of the existing works on
smart manufacturing are still limited to the theoretical level,
and some small manufacturing issues are solved. But speciﬁc
methods for systematic applications are deﬁcient and need to
be explored [ 13], [14], [15], [16].
In this article, the artiﬁcial systems, computational exper-
iments, and parallel execution (ACP) method is applied for
solving manufacturing issues to develop a new manufacturing
framework and explores its systematic application for produc-
ing shoes. Therefore, the main contributions of this article are
highlighted as follows.
1) Based on the ACP method, DeFACT is introduced as a
framework for parallel manufacturing in ManuVerse to
take full advantage of collective wisdom and real-virtual
interactions for achieving the rapid transformation from
demands to products, contributing to strongly competi-
tive products and low inventory.

4) The case of customized shoes of SANBODY

This article is organized as follows. Section II introduces
related works about CPS, CPSS, Metaverse, and ManuVerse
as well as smart manufacturing. The DeFACT framework for
parallel manufacturing, including parallel workers and manu-
facturing foundation models (MF) is elaborated in Section III
and then a DeFACT-based case is studied from three aspects:
workﬂow and production line named FlexVega, collaborations
between parallel workers, and challenges and solutions for
ﬂexible manufacturing, in Section IV. Finally, we conclude
this article in Section V.
II. R
ELATED WORKS
In this section, we introduce the concepts of CPS, CPSS,
metaverses, and ManuVerse as well as the relationships
between them at ﬁrst. Then, we give a brief description of
research works about smart manufacturing from CPS-based
and CPSS-based aspects and analyze the existing issues.
A. CPS, CPSS, Metaverse, and ManuVerse
The term CPS was created by National Science Foundation
(NSF) in the United States around 2006 [ 17], which describes
multidimensional complex systems occupying cyber and phys-
ical dimension, and is marked by a tight integration between
computation, communication, and control in their operations
and interactions with their surroundings [ 18]. The continuous
improvement in networked levels enables humans to become
the most agile social sensors and be pulled into an information
ecosystem that combines cyberspace and physicspace [ 19],
which conversely exert a signiﬁcant inﬂuence on human think-
ing and behaviors. As a result, CPS is no longer suitable for
human-in-the-loop manufacturing systems.
For exhaustive consideration of human and social factors
in complex systems, the concept of CPSS was introduced
in the late 1990s [ 7], which is based on Karl Popper’s the-
ory of reality that states our universe is composed of the
physical, mental, and artiﬁcial world, as illustrated in Fig. 1.
The development stage of the concept of IT has been under-
going from “Old IT (Industrial Technology)” to “Past IT
(Information Technology),” and then to “New IT (Intelligent
Technology),” tackling the resource disparity, the information
disparity and the intellectual disparity, respectively [ 11]. In
CPSS, three types of IT coexist, whereby cyber systems, phys-
ical systems, and social systems interact and entangle with
each other, contributing to unifying the contradiction between
Fig. 1. CPSS based on popper’s three worlds.
emergence and convergence. CPSS is taken as the infrastruc-
ture of smart manufacturing in the next stage of Industry 4.0,
namely, Industry 5.0, which will elevate AI to hybrid intel-
ligence (HI) [ 11]. Based on CPSS, complex manufacturing
systems can be managed and controlled more efﬁciently to
better coordinate and integrate assorted resources, such as
physics, computing, and society.
The concept of metaverse, which is becoming a hot trendy
concept all over the world, is explained by Matthew Ball
as “a massively scaled and interoperable network of real-
time rendered three-dimensional (3-D) virtual worlds,” which
any number of users can “synchronously and persistently”
enter by using “continuity of data,” such as “identity, his-
tory, entitlements, objects, communications, and payments” for
immersive experience [ 20]. As stated in [ 21] and [ 22], the
metaverse is essentially equivalent to CPSS and both are only
different names. The use of metaverses in the manufacturing
ﬁeld can form a new manufacturing ecology involving econ-
omy, trust, and immersive experience, named as ManuVerse,
through a series of ITs, such as digital twins, social comput-
ing, blockchain, and DAO [ 10], [ 23], [ 24], [ 25], [ 26], [ 27].
In ManuVerse, humans, machines, and objects are seamlessly
connected and incorporated into the physical industry, and they
have their own avatars that live and run in parallel.
B. Smart Manufacturing
Smart manufacturing is the application of advanced intel-
ligent technologies in manufacturing industry, where engi-
neers’ skills and experts’ knowledge are modeled through the
integration of knowledge engineering, machine control, soft-
ware systems, and artiﬁcial intelligence to enable intelligent
robots perform customized production without human inter-
vention [1], [28], [29]. The main target of smart manufacturing
is to achieve a new production way of various properties, such
as self-perception, self-learning, self-decision, self-execution,
and self-adaptation. As time passed by, smart manufacturing
has experienced two stages: 1) CPS-based manufacturing and
2) CPSS-based manufacturing.
CPS-based manufacturing has developed some typical rep-
resentatives from different perspectives [ 30], [31], [32], [33],
[34], [35], [36]. wireless manufacturing (WM), and ubiquitous
manufacturing (UbiM) are dedicated to the effective collection
and processing of real-time data in manufacturing and are uti-
lized to construct advanced functionality and infrastructures
2190 IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON SYSTEMS, MAN, AND CYBERNETICS: SYSTEMS, VOL. 53, NO. 4, APRIL 2023
for operations of physical devices in CPS [ 30], [ 31], [ 32].
Different from them, service-oriented manufacturing (SOM)
focuses on the cyber dimension of CPS-based manufactur-
ing, aiming at managing the service composition and business
processes [ 15], including industrial product-service systems
(IPSS) [33] and cloud manufacturing [34], [35]. As SoM mod-
els, IPSS integrates products and services into a system for
the servitization of enterprises so as to put the company at
an advantage in completion with others [ 33], whereas cloud
manufacturing pays more attention to the improvement on
user experience by delivering ﬂexible and on-demand man-
ufacturing services [ 34], [ 35]. Recently, digital twin-based
manufacturing (DTM) has attracted extensive attention. DTM
digitalizes physical production resources as their digital coun-
terparts and contributes to making full use of production data
through interactions between physical and virtual systems for
effective control and real-time optimization of manufactur-
ing [ 36]. Obviously, CPS-based manufacturing ignores the
important impact of human and social factors on the actual
manufacturing process, although it is capable of achieving
passable conjoining and interactions between cyberspace and
physicspace.
Since the emergence of CPSS, which further enhances
the fusion of cyberspace and physicspace and incorpo-
rates the complexity of human and social factors into
consideration, research on CPSS-based manufacturing has
been carried out [ 13], [ 14], [ 15], [ 16]. new generation
AI-driven intelligent manufacturing (NGAIIM) integrates
human/machine/environment/information into product lifecy-
cle activities with an emphasis on the introduction of new
generation AI for realizing manufacturing intelligence [ 13].
Wisdom manufacturing is a manufacturing paradigm of
humans–computers–things collaboration with the integration
of IoT, Internet of Services (IoS), Internet of Knowledge (IoK),
and Internet of People (IoP), which combines and extends the
concepts of cloud manufacturing, semantic network manufac-
turing, enterprise 2.0, and IoT manufacturing [ 15]. Inspired by
a 5C level structure of CPS [37], a data-centric 7C level frame-
work of CPSS serves to handle heterogeneous data along the
data-information-knowledge-wisdom pyramid for the support
of social manufacturing [16]. As we can see, the existing work
for CPSS-based manufacturing is still conﬁned to the frame-
works and structures for the organization of resources and few
speciﬁc methods are provided to deal with the complexity and
unpredictability of human-in-the-loop manufacturing systems.
Parallel manufacturing, as an important milestone of smart
manufacturing, is based on the ACP method, providing a
feasible solution to make human-in-the-loop manufacturing
systems computable, testable, and veriﬁable. It constructs par-
allel production systems to achieve real-virtual interactions and
interactive optimization for the management and control of
complex systems during the manufacturing process [ 38], [39],
[40], [41]. To further develop more intelligent parallel manu-
facturing, in this article, DeFACT is introduced as a framework
for parallel manufacturing in ManuVerse, where the coopera-
tion of parallel workers and a manufacturing foundation model
named MF-PC to aid in the development of digital workers
are elaborated.
III. D
EFACT FOR PARALLEL MANUFACTURING
In this section, the framework of DeFACT for parallel man-
ufacturing is introduced and then the DAO-based interactions
between parallel workers consisting of robotic workers, digital
workers, and human workers are elaborated to transform from
professional division to real-virtual division. Finally, as the
cornerstone of digital workers, MF-PC is proposed to further
intensify their perceptual and cognitive intelligence, achieving
industrial development for fragmented applications.
A. DeFACT Framework: Management and Control
The framework of DeFACT in ManuVerse is illustrated in
Fig. 2 for the management and control of parallel manufac-
turing, which aims at upgrading six indexes of manufactur-
ing systems, i.e., safety index, security index, sustainability
index, sensitivity index, service index, and smartness index,
to realize six kinds of intelligence, i.e., cognitive intelli-
gence, parallel intelligence, encrypted intelligence, federated
intelligence, social intelligence, and ecological intelligence,
through advanced intelligent technology, such as ACP [ 21],
KA [10], blockchain [ 9], smart contracts [ 26], cognitive com-
puting [ 42], scenarios engineering (SE) [ 43], and foundation
models [44].
In DeFACT, social intelligence is collected, integrated, and
analyzed into social demands for rapid response to market
and policy changes, thus leading to zero inventory produc-
tion. Collective wisdom is gathered and taken full advantage
of to create products through crowdsourcing [ 45] via com-
puters and mobile phones, which breaks the limitation of
individual capacities and the communication barriers. Inspired
by circular causality [ 46], based on ACP, parallel evolu-
tion, closed-loop feedback, and collaborative optimization for
a series of manufacturing operations are achieved through
real-virtual interactions between actual systems and artiﬁ-
cial systems in factories. Digital workers and robotic workers
undertake almost all the work, accounting for 80% and 15%,
respectively, while human workers concentrate on the more
complex and creative rest, with a proportion of 5%. The
paradigm is more ﬂexible and robust against disturbances,
whereby human workers can pay more attention to extremely
complex and creative tasks.
A manufacturing system is regarded as a typical CPSS
according to DeFACT, which consists of physical systems
for totally integrated automation, cyber systems for product
life-cycle management, and social systems for manufacturing
intelligence. Physical systems are collections of production
elements that exist objectively, including human workers,
equipment, robotic workers, materials, sensors, semi-ﬁnished
products, etc. Compared to traditional manufacturing systems,
those systems have the ability to perceive, access and inte-
grate heterogeneous real-time data from sensors supported
by different protocols, that is, the heterogeneous network
and data fusion technology play a vital role [ 47], [48], [49].
Cyber systems are used for the operation and management
of physical systems and social systems, including com-
puter hardware, communication equipment, computer soft-
ware, information resources, etc., where the utilization of

cloud/fog/edge computing for high computational efﬁciency
requires the data security and privacy protection technology
to avoid causing ﬁnancial loss or reputational damage for
humans and enterprises [ 50], [51]. Humans in social systems
are incorporated into the manufacturing system, acting as dif-

In terms of ACP, DeFACT constructs one or many artiﬁcial
systems as software-deﬁned social laboratories for compu-
tational experiments, namely, descriptive intelligence, which
are not direct, mechanical, passive, and mirror reﬂections of,
and thus not completely consistent with the actual manu-
facturing system [ 22]. Those systems are treated as some
alternative realities of different evolutionary directions [ 55],
where a variety of manufacturing behaviors and phenomena,
especially those involving human and social factors, are repro-
duced and analyzed to acquire their occurrence reasons and
different related solutions are tested and evaluated for choos-
ing the optimal, whereby predictive intelligence is generated.
Once chosen, the optimal solution is straightforwardly applied
for the actual system. It is worth nothing that the solution
is not static but dynamically optimized during parallel exe-
cution through real-virtual interactions between the actual
system and its artiﬁcial counterparts for prescriptive intelli-
gence. This contributes to adaptation to unanticipated external
changes in a timely manner. In addition, during computational
experiments, to handle prevalent problems in industrial scenar-
ios, i.e., insufﬁcient and unbalanced data, some methods are
used to built and generate virtual data based on real data for
data augmentation, such as SE [ 43], variational autoencoder
(V AE) [56], generative adversarial network (GAN) [ 57], and
diffusion model (DM) [ 58].
Besides, DeFACT conjoins the actual system with its arti-
ﬁcial counterparts in three modes for different intentions, i.e.,
learning and training, experimentation and evaluation, and
control and management [ 59]. In the learning and training
mode, artiﬁcial systems are treated as a center of learning
and training operational procedures for parallel workers. In
the experimentation and evaluation mode, artiﬁcial systems
are used as social laboratories combining computers and
cyberspace, where “small data” is transformed into “big data”
and then “deep intelligence” is extracted and condensed. By
this means, different solutions can be tested and evaluated
quickly and efﬁciently. In the control and management mode,
based on generalized circular causality and circular logic, his-
torical data, current scenarios and future visions form a closed

portrayed by artiﬁcial systems.
B. Parallel Workers: From Professional Division to
Real-Virtual Division
In DeFACT, there are three types of workers named parallel
workers: 1) human workers with intuitive rationality; 2) digital
workers with computational rationality; and 3) robotic workers
with adaptive rationality, in collaboration with each other for
accomplishing production, which brings about transforming
traditional professional division into real-virtual division [ 46].
Robotic workers are intelligent machines that dominate physi-
cal work, digital workers are comprised of intelligent programs
and information machines, with the same appearances as
humans, which are equivalent to the “brain” of humans for
mental work; whereas human workers mainly concentrate
on more difﬁcult and creative tasks beyond the capabilities
of the former two, such as the maintenance and upgrades
of equipment and the correction of failed results, in liber-
ation from tedious noncreative labor. This mode contributes
to sufﬁciently leveraging intellectual resources. Additionally,
nonhuman workers can run efﬁciently and continuously with-
out salaries, resulting in increased productivity and reduced
costs.
Fig. 3 illustrates the DAO-based organization and
interaction mode between parallel workers. Digital workers
acting as the core of interactions are organized into a DAO
where information is communicated and exchanged. A DAO
is a ﬂexible and open organization without central authority or
management hierarchy, of which all operational rules depend
on collective decisions and are encoded on tamper-resistant
blockchains [ 25]. Robotic workers are execution units for
physical tasks according to control commands mostly from
digital workers. Due to enjoying the top priority, human
workers have the ability to enforce the direct command
of robotic workers and the modiﬁcation of knowledge and
decisions of digital workers via human–machine interfaces
(HMIs). The correspondence between parallel workers and
tasks can be not only one-to-one but also one-to-many as
well as many-to-many, which is dependent on the required
computational or operational capabilities and the complexity
of tasks. Once digital workers become available, they will
compute and rank the remaining tasks and list the related
requirements for accomplishing them, such as time and
resources, especially idle robotic workers. Based on those
ranking and requirements, every digital worker can draft and
launch proposals for the allocation of missions and resources.
After considerable discussions about the proposals in the
organization, every member must make decisions: agreement
or disagreement. If the proposals meet with the approval of
the majority, they will be recorded by smart contracts and
executed by everyone.
Clearly, digital workers exert a critical part in DeFACT-
based production and their intelligence is divided into two
aspects: 1) cognitive intelligence and 2) perceptual intelli-
gence. For perceptual intelligence, digital workers should have
similar perceptual abilities to humans, such as vision, hearing,
and touch, [ 60] and can interact with external surroundings
through machine learning technologies, such as natural lan-
guage processing (NLP), computer vision (CV), and speech
recognition (SV) [ 61], [ 62], [ 63]. For cognitive intelligence,
digital workers should be capable of reasoning analogous with
human brains by using methods of psychology, biology, sig-
nal processing, information theory, physics, mathematics, and
statistics, called as cognitive computing [ 64]. Cognitive com-
puting is a core technical ﬁeld of cognitive science, with the
properties of assistance, understanding, decision, and discov-
ery, which studies humans’ cognitive behaviors and integrate
them with intelligent algorithms to solve highly complex prob-
lems [64], [65]. Currently, robotic process automation (RPA)
is widely used to perform duplicate work in computers accord-
ing to human demonstration, which represents the beginning
of digital workers, and obviously more intelligence needs to
be developed [ 66].

C. Manufacturing Foundation Models: The Cornerstone of
Digital Workers
Customized small models for specialized tasks have dif-
ﬁculties in adapting to fragmented manufacturing scenario
requirements due to long periods and high costs of devel-
opment. And, the prevalence of small data scenes results
in difﬁculties in guaranteeing the accuracy of those mod-
els [ 67], [ 68]. The birth of transformer architecture allows
deep learning models to have hundreds of millions of parame-
ters [69], improving their expressiveness, so a huge paradigm
shift toward big models has been occurring, transforming
development from workshop to industrialization, without large
amounts of labeled data [ 44]. A big model is also known as a
foundation model or a pretrained model, which is regarded as
the cornerstone of digital workers and can further enhance
their perceptual and cognitive intelligence. Currently, NLP
big models (e.g., BERT [ 70] and GPT-3 [ 71]), CV big mod-
els (e.g., V-MoE [ 72] and ViT [ 73]), and multimodal big
models (e.g., DALL ·E[ 74], DreamFusion [ 75], and Make-
A-Video [ 76]) have been developed, which are ulteriorly
specialized as ﬁeld big models or business big models accord-
ing to speciﬁc ﬁelds or tasks [ 77] and thus realize the “small
problems, big models, small tasks, and big operations” target.
To strengthen the intelligence of digital workers in manufac-
turing scenarios and improve the efﬁciency of development for
customized models, this article proposes an MF with percep-
tual intelligence and cognitive intelligence (PC), as illustrated
in Fig. 4, which is composed of ﬁve modules: 1) SE; 2) knowl-
edge graph embedding; 3) single-modal feature extraction;
4) multimodal feature and knowledge fusion; and 5) pretrained
tasks.
Traditionally, before algorithms are trained, feature engi-
neering must be performed to extract the most appropri-
ate features of the raw data in order to achieve the best
performance [78], [79], [80]. Currently, although it has become
the mainstream of feature engineering in machine learn-
ing [ 81], [ 82], which greatly exploits the feature potential
for raw data, representation learning reduces interpretability
and reliability to humans [ 83], [84], [85]. To deal with those
issues, in MF-PC, SE, including calibration and certiﬁcation
(C&C), and veriﬁcation and validation (V&V) are applied to
guarantee humans’ visibility into the work of the machine
and the controllability of learning features, thus achieving
trust in AI [ 43], so in the module, multisource heteroge-
neous knowledge and data embedded in manufacturing CPSS
are preprocessed to prepare for subsequent operations, such
as generating knowledge graph embedding and augmenting
data [57], [86], [87].
To learn the implicit laws behind the data, considering
the different data formats, a single-modal featured extraction
module is designed based on transformers to extract single-
modal features from data in various formats, respectively.
Beneﬁting from their advantages, including better capture
of long-term dependencies than convolution neural networks
(CNNs) and suitability for parallel computing [ 69
], [88], self-
attention mechanisms are introduced to acquire the internal
correlation of data or features. Because of the strong corre-
lation between signal-modal features, a multimodal feature
and knowledge fusion module with cross-modal attention is
developed to integrate cross-modal interactions and achieve
multiview portrayals of manufacturing scenes, inspired by
the multimodal transformer [ 89], [ 90]. Additionally, knowl-
edge graph embedding [ 91] is incorporated to contribute to
improving the expression of models.
MF-PC is trained by self-supervised learning, whereby the
supervised information is mined from a large amount of unsu-
pervised data by using the auxiliary tasks and then networks
are trained with the constructed supervised information with-
out the prelabeled data [ 92]. Therefore, the design of pre-
trained tasks is crucial to the effectiveness of models adapted
to downstream services. For example, pretrained tasks of
self-supervised learning for NLP include masked language
modeling (MLM), next sequence prediction (NSP), sentence
order prediction (SOP), etc; pretrained tasks for CV include

IV . C
ASE STUDY
A. Workﬂow and Production Line: FlexVega
The DeFACT framework has been realized successfully in
SANBODY Technology Company, which possesses the auto-
mated workﬂow of shoes with transformation for demands,
such as personalized customization to competitive products
(see Fig. 5), making it possible for on-demand production. The
contours of customers’ feet are captured via 3-D scanners and
modeled by using 3-D construction algorithms. Subsequently,
the 3-D models of shoe lasts are designed and made auto-
matically rather than manually, which the styles and comforts
of shoes rely on. And everyone, including prosumers can
participate and cooperate in the creation of shoe fashions
through Cyber Movement Organizations (CMOs) [ 24]. After
customers’ satisfaction with the design, the closed contracted
factories to their locations are found to execute production
in a real-virtual interactive way. The ﬁnished shoes can be
delivered to customers through logistics distribution.
In the factory, based on CV , an unmanned production line
of shoes named FlexVega (see Fig. 6) has been established,
where 25 structured light sensors and ten mechanical arms are
deployed, resulting in a gratifying achievement, i.e., a decrease
from 36 to 1 in the number of human workers while double
production capacity. Almost all of the operations, including
loading and unloading, edge roughing, spraying glue, and
detaching shoe lasts, are completely automated, allowing sim-
pletons to switch the production of different styles via a
control system. As a result, human workers do not need to
be exposed to unpleasant and potentially harmful working
conditions. Obviously, DeFACT can get rid of the time and
space restrictions, reduce human intervention, and avoid pro-
duction waste resulting from aesthetic discrepancies between
consumers.

B. Collaborations Between Parallel Workers
For a better understanding of the cooperative relationships
between three types of parallel workers, their collaborative
process of spraying glue on the soles is demonstrated as
an instance in Fig. 7. After two-dimensional (2-D)/3-D data
of soles is sensed and obtained by structured light sensors,
glue-spraying trajectories are computed based on redeﬁned
algorithms by digital workers and then are transmitted to the
robotic workers. Thereafter, the received commands are fol-
lowed to spray glue on soles along those trajectories by robotic
workers, that is, mechanical arms. To evaluate whether the
qualities of glue-spraying meet the requirements (precision ≤
1 mm), sensors are leveraged to remeasure 2-D/3-D data of
glue-sprayed soles, and then digital workers compute their
precision by using the predeﬁned evaluation algorithm. If the
precision is more than 1 mm, which means their spraying
effects are terrible, rectiﬁcation should be executed by human
workers, so robotic workers should place the corresponding
soles in a speciﬁed convenient location. Otherwise, this means
that the success of spraying is reached and the soles will be
sent to the next step, where digital workers are taken as a
bridge of communication. Afterward, human workers will do
their efforts to correct the faults caused by nonhuman workers.
During the current step, the evaluation algorithm is con-
structed through CNNs in digital workers. To solve the

C. Flexible Manufacturing: Challenges and Solutions
For the achievement of great glue-spraying effects of shoes,
edge roughing around upper contours and spraying trajectory
planning are critical steps, where two issues that contribute to
increased errors must be addressed (see Fig. 9).
1) The 3-D contours of shoes are intricate and unique,
especially their uppers. Even shoes of identical styles
and sizes are different in their subtleties because of the
process precision.
2) The edges of soles and their corresponding uppers can
not match perfectly and they are nonrigid and prone to
deformation when bonded.
Generally, most companies perform the related procedures
based on the following assumptions: 1) shoes of identical
styles and sizes have the same 3-D contours; 2) shoes are
regarded to be rigid and not deformable; and 3) the edges
of soles can match perfectly with their corresponding uppers.
In those companies, engineers conduct manual glue spray-
ing once as a demonstration and then automated equipment
follow the demonstrated trajectories to spray all the shoes
exactly [12]. As a consequence, if shoes are identical in styles
and sizes but different in subtleties, they will be sprayed along
the same paths, which suffers from large errors of spraying
glue.
To tackle those issues, FlexVega leverages 3-D visual
scanning, 3-D deformation simulation, and deformation-based
trajectory planning as three vital technologies for the achieve-
ment of ﬂexible manufacturing with regard to spraying glue

After uppers are roughed for ensuring great peel strength, the
deformation-based trajectory planning technology is applied
to compute roughing and spraying trajectories according to
upper and sole contours, where CNNs are constructed for
self-learning correction. Similarly, NURBS serves interpola-
tion for generating smooth and continuous paths. Afterward,
robotic workers perform the movements of roughing and
spraying glue ﬂexibly along the acquired paths without the
engineer’s demonstrations. Fig. 10 illustrates the procedures of

utilized to test the effects of roughing trajectory planning, as

39, we try to leverage size 40 soles to match size 39 uppers
and still obtain a good trajectory planning effect. In conclu-
sion, FlexVega can produce them no matter what type of shoes.
This means that the most challenging core difﬁculties of ﬂex-
ible manufacturing have been addressed, which stands for a
revolutionary advance.
V. C
ONCLUSION
We introduced the DeFACT framework for smart manu-
facturing, speciﬁcally for the parallel manufacturing paradigm,
and illustrated how it solves the problems of uncertainty, diver-
sity, complexity in modeling, long-delayed responses to market
changes, and human engineer dependency in smart factories.
The DAO-based interaction, ACP, and MF-PC are introduced
as core methodologies in DeFACT. Also, a case study of cus-
tomized shoe workﬂow, especially the unmanned production
line named FlexVega is taken as an example of DeFACT.
Accordingly, DeFACT is proved to be a revolutionary break-
through for solving the most difﬁcult core problems of ﬂexible
manufacturing.
